channel.title: What to do when your validator node can't connect to the official Radix seed nodes
channel.description:
A new Radix node contacts one or more seed nodes to get a list of other nodes on the network when it starts up. If the node is unable to connect to one of the [official Radix seed nodes](https://radixtalk.com/t/what-are-the-official-radix-seed-node-addresses/195), then the node will stall.
The seed node is specified in the `default.config` file under the `network.p2p.seed_nodes` key
```text network.p2p.seed_nodes=radix://rn1qvw5v4w8llexz99uc9gmeh47qp2h9ax2y3aewm5e6vj5sdx8uuph2vfuvg3@3.221.232.135 ```
It is possible to specify multiple seed nodes by separating them with a comma: ```text network.p2p.seed_nodes=radix://rn1qvw5v4w8llexz99uc9gmeh47qp2h9ax2y3aewm5e6vj5sdx8uuph2vfuvg3@3.221.232.135,radix://rn1qtq336a2nn2269fjes53pynwlytrv0katm6uzlfcyl6m7yscac5g7mh8prw@3.220.101.80,radix://rn1qwa45jjf40vuf9xlq85xym86yegnm95h3g8d4lul5hskrws9gm6ykyx7hsf@3.214.160.245 ```
The good news is that any node on the Radix network can act as a seed node - as long as you know the IP address of the node and node address (rdx1....).
Seed nodes have the following URI format:
`radix://rn1....@ip.address`
The `rn1...` part is the **Radix Node Address** that is used during the Radix node handshake protocol to created a shared secret for encrypted communication between the two nodes.
Convert the Validator Address into a Node Address: https://radixtalk.com/t/how-to-convert-a-validator-address-rdx-into-a-node-address-rn/196
See also: https://radixtalk.com/t/what-community-archive-nodes-can-i-use-with-the-radix-desktop-wallet/156
